repository.corpname: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

did.unittitle: Abraham Lincoln Brigade Archives Subject Files

physdesc.extent: in 6 record cartons, 10 manuscript boxes, 4 oversized flat boxes, 1 flat box, 1 flat file, and 1 shared manuscript box

did.abstract: The Abraham Lincoln Brigade Archives (ALBA) Subject Files (1930-ongoing) are a rich source for background information on the people, events and topics related to the ALBA collections in the Tamiment Library and include coverage of the International Brigades as well. The files contain a variety of documents such as newspaper clippings, flyers, brochures, biographical material, anniversary and exhibit programs, obituaries, and other items. Consult the folder list in this collection to find material on specific events or topics. See the ALBA Vertical File on Individuals to find biographical material on specific individuals.
did.langmaterial: Materials are primarily in English. Some materials are in Spanish, French, and Czech.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Abraham Lincoln Brigade Archives (ALBA) Subject Files (1930-ongoing) consists of files of printed ephemera such as broadsides, brochures, bulletins, catalogs, clippings, flyers, leaflets, manifestoes, pamphlets, press releases, reports, reprints and other documents relating to a broad range of subjects connected with the Abraham Lincoln Brigade.

custodhist.head: Provenance
custodhist.p: The provenance of the materials is varied. Items were obtained through purchases, donations, standing orders with publishers, arrangements with organizations and bookstores, exchanges with other libraries, and through ongoing collecting by Tamiment staff.

http://www.alba-valb.org/ and http://albavolunteer.org/ were initially selected by curators and captured through the use of The California Digital Library's Web Archiving Service in 2008 and 2010, respectively, as part of the Other Left Activism Web Archive. In November 2015, this website was migrated to Archive-It. Archive-It uses web crawling technology to capture websites at a scheduled time and displays only an archived copy, from the resulting WARC file, of the website. In 2017, http://resources.alba-valb.org/ was added. In 2021, https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC_eG6lzX4KJPYIHDZCb-LFw/videos/ was added. The accession number associated with this website is 2022.024. In 2023, https://www.youtube.com/@abrahamlincolnbrigadearchi4395/videos/ was added. The accession number associated with this website is 2023.086.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Materials are open to researchers. Please contact the Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives for more information and to schedule an appointment, tamiment.wagner@nyu.edu or 212-998-2630.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: Because of the assembled nature of this collection, copyright status varies across the collection. Copyrights held by original creators of individual items in the collection are expected to pass into the public domain 120 years after their creation. Any rights (including copyright and related rights to publicity and privacy) held by the Abraham Lincoln Brigade Archives (ALBA) were transferred to New York University in November 2000 by the ALBA Board of Governors. Permission to publish or reproduce ALBA materials must be secured from the Tamiment Library & Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives. For more information, contact tamiment.wagner@nyu.edu or 212-998-2630.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date (if known); Abraham Lincoln Brigade Archives Subject Files; ALBA VF 001; Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archive, New York University.

To cite the archived website in this collection: Identification of item, date; Abraham Lincoln Brigade Archives Subject Files; ALBA VF 001; Wayback URL; Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archive, New York University.

appraisal.head: Take Down Policy
appraisal.p: Archived websites are made accessible for purposes of education and research. NYU Libraries have given attribution to rights holders when possible; however, due to the nature of archival collections, we are not always able to identify this information.
If you hold the rights to materials in our archived websites that are unattributed, please let us know so that we may maintain accurate information about these materials.

If you are a rights holder and are concerned that you have found material on this website for which you have not granted permission (or is not covered by a copyright exception under US copyright laws), you may request the removal of the material from our site by submitting a notice, with the elements described below, to the special.collections@nyu.edu.

Please include the following in your notice: Identification of the material that you believe to be infringing and information sufficient to permit us to locate the material; your contact information, such as an address, telephone number, and email address; a statement that you are the owner, or authorized to act on behalf of the owner, of an exclusive right that is allegedly infringed and that you have a good-faith belief that use of the material in the manner complained of is not authorized by the copyright owner, its agent, or the law; a statement that the information in the notification is accurate and made under penalty of perjury; and your physical or electronic signature. Upon receiving a notice that includes the details listed above, we will remove the allegedly infringing material from public view while we assess the issues identified in your notice.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: In March 2022, archived websites were added to the finding and additonal description was updated. In additional website was added in 2023.

In September 2024, materials housed in Box 3, a record carton, were rehoused into four manuscript boxes (Boxes 3, 13-15). Oversized materials were rehoused into a flat box and two oversized flat boxes (Shared Tamiment Box 169, Shared Tamiment Box 175, and Shared Tamiment Box 184). At this time, materials were placed into new archival folders and original titles were maintained. New York University Libraries follow professional standards and best practices when imaging, ingesting, and processing born-digital material in order to maintain the integrity and authenticity of the content. During this rehousing, one optical disc was identified and inventoried. It was then analyzed and arranged using Forensic Toolkit.

In 2025, unprocessed materials from the Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives Printed Ephemera Collection on Subjects (PE 029) were transferred to this collection and placed in new acid-free folders and boxes. These materials were housed in box Shared Tamiment 193 and integrated into the collection's existing alphabetical file list.

phystech.head: Born-Digital Access Policies and Procedures
phystech.p: An access terminal for born-digital materials in the collection is available by appointment for reading room viewing and listening only. Researchers may view an item's original container and/or carrier, but the physical carriers themselves are not available for use because of preservation concerns.

accruals.head: Accruals
accruals.p: New site crawls are accrued semiannually.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: Due to technical or privacy issues, archived websites may not be exact copies of the original website at the time of the web crawl. Certain file types will not be captured dependent on how they are embedded in the site. Other parts of websites that the crawler has difficulty capturing includes Javascript, streaming content, database-driven content, and highly interactive content. Full-Text searches of archived websites are available at https://archive-it.org/organizations/567.

appraisal.head: Appraisal
appraisal.p: Crawl was limited to domains and subdomains of alba-valb.org and albavolunteer.org in order to remain within the collection scope and data constraints.
YouTube Channel was added to attempt to capture the videos embedded in the website. In 2023, YouTube URLs were changed to better capture the videos on the channel.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Abraham Lincoln Brigade Archives (ALBA) is dedicated to preserving and communicating the history and memory of those Americans who participated in the Spanish Civil War on the Republican side ("volunteers"). It is also successor to the Veterans of the Abraham Lincoln Brigade. The website was first collected in 2008 and contained history of the war and the veterans organizations; dgitized documents, audio, images, and video related to the volunteers; a database of the volunteers with biographies; exhibit catalogs; online lesson plans for teaching about the Spanish Civil War; the San Francisco Monument; book reviews; events; ALBA in the news; George Watt Essay Contest; Teaching Institutes; and information about the ALBA collections at the Tamiment Library. Overtime, content on the website increased to include online resources of other institutions with Abraham Lincoln Brigade collections; a glossary; ALBA's Robeson in Spain comic book; publications on the Abraham Lincoln Brigade; fundraising efforts; ALBA/Puffin Award for Human Rights Activism; Human Rights Documentary Film Festival; obituaries; staff biographies; and the Susman lecture series. In early 2020, the website redesigned. Additional projects documented on the website include information on the Jarama Society; "Invisible Heroes: African Americans in the Spanish Civil War" documentary; the Perry Rosenstein Cultural Series; annual galas; and the Good Fight fundraising campaign.

They also publish the quarterly journal, The Volunteer. Capture of the Volunteer's website began in 2010. The journal covers interviews, essays, obituaries, book reviews and other reviews, videos, research news, exhibitions, Tamiment Library updates, the Passport project and other database updates, speeches and presentations, the history of progressive activism, letters to the editor, current events interpreted through the lens of the Spanish Civil War, and other news related to the Spanish Civil War and the volunteers. Back issues of the Volunteer on the website date back to 1938.

The YouTube Channel contains videos related to virtual events and galas put on by ALBA during the COVID-19 pandemic. Topics include the memorial for Judy Montell, fundraising videos, Question and Answer panels on books and films related to the Abraham Lincoln Brigade, Memorial and Veterans Days tributes; Susman Lectures; other lectures; and monument commemorations.
